security: Recommending against declassification due to valid points made by Sir Charles Spry regarding the investigation of anonymous telephone calls could reveal intelligence gathering methods. Quoting directly: 'Sir Charles' letter to you recommends against declassification of the Warren Commission document CD-971 which refers to our investigation of anonymous telephone calls to the Canberra Embassy before and after the assassination of President Kennedy.'
summary: A memorandum to the Director of Central Intelligence recommends against declassifying Warren Commission document CD-971 based on concerns raised by Sir Charles Spry of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization (ASIO) regarding the investigation of anonymous telephone calls to the Canberra Embassy.
summary_one_paragraph: This SECRET memorandum, dated November 20, 1968, from William H. Nelson, Chief of the Far East Division, to the Director of Central Intelligence, via the Deputy Director for Plans, addresses a letter from Sir Charles Spry, Director General of ASIO. Sir Charles advises against the declassification of Warren Commission document CD-971, which details the investigation into anonymous telephone calls made to the Canberra Embassy before and after President Kennedy's assassination. Nelson concurs with Spry's assessment and recommends that CD-971 remain classified.
title: Letter for Director from Sir Charles Spry (ASIO)
sender: William H. Nelson, Chief, Far East Division
